Award.AwardTitle: Conference on Statistical Machine Learning and Data Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill will host a three day conference on Statistical Machine Learning and Data Science from June 6-8, 2016. (See http://www.unc.edu/~yfliu/sldm2016/.) The objective is to bring together researchers in statistical learning and data science from academia, industry, and government in a stimulating atmosphere focused on the development of statistical learning theory, methods and applications. Statistical machine learning is a relatively new discipline, evolving from machine learning methods of artificial intelligence and multivariate statistics. It also plays an essential role for the new important area of data science and big data. NSF funding will provide travel support to increase the number of junior researchers who are able to attend.

The Section on Statistical Machine Learning and Data Science of the American Statistical Association will hold a meeting at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill from June 6-8, 2016. Topics of the conference include, but are not limited to, big data analytics, classification, computational biology, covariance estimation, graphical models, high dimensional data, learning theory, model selection, network analysis, precision medicine, and signal and image processing. This award will provide travel support for junior researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goals of the project are to organize the biannual conference of the American Statistical Association's (ASA) Section on Statistical Learning and Data Science, held during June 5-8, 2016 on the Chapel Hill campus of University of North Carolina. The objective of the conference was to bring together researchers in statistical learning and data science from academia, industry, and government in a relaxed and stimulating atmosphere.

 The conference program provided a useful guide for researchers and practitioners on the principles and methods that apply to statistical learning and data science. The conference helped to provide a great platform for researchers to share their research results and learn other developments in the area. The conference program included 3 plenary talks, 33 invited sections, and 25 posters. The organizers spent great effort to encourage women and underrepresented groups to attend the conference. The scientific activities provided the participants great opportunities to learn the most cutting edge developments in statistical machine learning and data science.

The organizers spent effort to promote interactions among participants, which can be especially valuable for junior faculty and graduate students. This NSF project helped to support a number of young researchers including students to attend this conference.
